acacia tree.note: Acacia tree – Durable wood used in building the tabernacle and Ark of the Covenant (Exodus 25:10).

almond.note: Almond – Symbol of watchfulness and divine choice, as in Aaron’s rod that budded (Numbers 17:8; Jeremiah 1:11).

almond tree.note: Almond tree – Symbol of watchfulness and early blooming, as seen in Aaron’s budding rod (Numbers 17:8; Jeremiah 1:11).

aloes.note: A fragrant wood or resin used in perfuming and burial, mingling sorrow with honor (John 19:39).

anise.note: Anise – A spice mentioned by Jesus when criticizing legalistic tithing (Matthew 23:23, KJV).

apple tree.note: A shade-giving tree invoked in love poetry, its fragrance and fruit evoking delight (Song of Songs 2:3).

balm of gilead.note: A healing resin famed for soothing wounds—longed for by a wounded nation (Jeremiah 8:22).

barley.note: Barley – A staple grain, often associated with the poor and used in offerings (John 6:9; Leviticus 23:10).

bay tree.note: An evergreen emblem of flourishing and stability, standing green in dry seasons (Psalm 37:35, KJV).

bitter herbs.note: Herbs of remembrance eaten with Passover, tasting the cost of deliverance (Exodus 12:8).

box tree.note: A strong evergreen used in temple adornment; a sign of lasting beauty (Isaiah 60:13, KJV).

bramble.note: Bramble – A thorny shrub used in Jotham’s parable to symbolize worthless leadership (Judges 9:14–15).

branch of jesse.note: A promised shoot from David’s line—humble beginnings, royal fruit (Isaiah 11:1).

branch of the lord.note: A name for the Messiah—beauty and glory growing from judgment to joy (Isaiah 4:2).

brier.note: Brier – A thorny plant representing judgment or obstacles in prophetic imagery (Isaiah 5:6; Ezekiel 28:24).

broom tree.note: A desert shrub that sheltered Elijah in his weakness, where God met him with bread and rest (1 Kings 19:4–8).

bulrush.note: Bulrush – A marsh plant used to make Moses’ basket and papyrus (Exodus 2:3; Isaiah 18:2).

calamus.note: Calamus – A fragrant reed used in the holy anointing oil (Exodus 30:23).

carob tree.note: A hardy tree of the Levant; its pods recall lean times in parables and tradition.

cassia.note: Cassia – A fragrant spice used in anointing oil and perfume (Psalm 45:8; Exodus 30:24).

cassia bark.note: A spice of anointing and royal perfume—garments scented with worship (Psalm 45:8; Exodus 30:24).

cedar.note: Cedar – A strong, aromatic wood used in Solomon’s temple and David’s palace (1 Kings 6:9–10).

cedar of lebanon.note: Majestic evergreen of Lebanon’s heights—symbol of strength, stature, and royal building (1 Kings 5–6; Psalm 92:12).

chestnut.note: Chestnut – Possibly referenced in some translations as a tree planted by water (Ezekiel 31:8, KJV).

cinnamon.note: Cinnamon – Aromatic spice included in the sacred anointing oil (Exodus 30:23).

coriander.note: Coriander – A plant whose seed resembled manna in appearance (Exodus 16:31; Numbers 11:7).

cummin.note: Cummin – An herb used in food and referenced by Jesus in teaching about tithing (Isaiah 28:25; Matthew 23:23).

cypress tree.note: Cypress tree – A valued wood used in temple construction and associated with strength (Isaiah 44:14).

dry tree.note: Symbol of judgment and barrenness—hope yet for the eunuch in God’s house (Ezekiel 17:24; Isaiah 56:3).

ebony.note: A dense, dark wood prized in trade—hint of distant coasts and skilled workmanship (Ezekiel 27:15).

fig tree.note: Fig tree – Represents peace, prosperity, and spiritual fruitfulness (Micah 4:4; Matthew 21:19).

figs.note: Figs – A common biblical fruit, symbolizing peace and security (1 Kings 4:25; Mark 11:13–14).

fir.note: Fir – Mentioned in translations as a tree used in temple construction and symbolic of strength (1 Kings 5:8–10; Isaiah 60:13).

frankincense.note: A sweet resin burned in worship and offered at Jesus’ birth—prayer rising like smoke (Matthew 2:11; Revelation 8:3–4).

galbanum.note: A resin blended into the holy incense, part of a fragrance reserved for God (Exodus 30:34–38).

gourd.note: A fast-growing plant that shaded Jonah—here and gone, a lesson in mercy (Jonah 4:6–10, KJV: ‘gourd’).

grapes.note: Grapes – Used for wine, symbolizing joy and abundance; central in communion symbolism (John 15:1–5; Matthew 26:29).

green tree.note: Image of vitality and favor; a living contrast to the dry tree (Luke 23:31).

hazel.note: Hazel – Mentioned as one of the rods Jacob used to influence livestock breeding (Genesis 30:37).

henna.note: A perfumed blossom of love poetry—clusters that scent the gardens of the heart (Song of Songs 1:14; 4:13).

hyacinth.note: A spring flower evoked in color and perfume; a breath of renewal after winter.

hyssop.note: Hyssop – Used in ceremonial cleansing and the application of Passover blood (Exodus 12:22; Psalm 51:7).

ivy.note: A clinging vine—beauty with a warning against idolatrous wreaths (2 Maccabees 6:7; cultural context).

juniper.note: An evergreen of the wilderness—its coals burn long; its shade shelters weary travelers (Job 30:4; Psalm 120:4).

laurel.note: An evergreen wreathing victors; a living image of reward and unfading crown (cf. 1 Peter 5:4).

lilies.note: Lilies – Symbol of beauty and God's care, referenced in Solomon's poetry and Jesus’ teaching (Song of Songs 2:2; Matthew 6:28–29).

lily of the valley.note: A delicate flower symbolizing purity and the sweetness of God’s presence (cf. Song of Songs 2:1).

lotus.note: A water flower evoked in poetry and trade—echoes of Nile country and calm waters (Job 40:21–22, alt. ‘lotus’).

mandrakes.note: Fragrant plants entangled in the hopes of Rachel and Leah—longings for life and love (Genesis 30:14–16).

mint.note: A garden herb Jesus named among meticulous tithes—calling us to justice and mercy (Matthew 23:23).

mulberry tree.note: Trees that rustled like marching hosts—God’s sign to David to advance (2 Samuel 5:24).

myrrh.note: A costly resin of anointing and burial; joy and sorrow mingled in one fragrance (Matthew 2:11; John 19:39).

myrtle blossom.note: Delicate blooms of the myrtle—the peace-filled counterpart to exile’s thorns (Isaiah 55:13).

myrtle tree.note: Myrtle tree – A symbol of peace and restoration in prophetic visions (Isaiah 41:19; Zechariah 1:8).

nard.note: A precious perfume poured out in devotion—love’s costly surrender (John 12:3; Mark 14:3).

nettle.note: A stinging weed that marks neglect and desolation—fields left to ruin (Proverbs 24:31).

oak.note: Oak – A large, strong tree often associated with altars, burial, or divine encounters (Genesis 35:8; Isaiah 6:13).

olive branch.note: A sign of peace and new beginnings from Noah’s day to ours (Genesis 8:11).

olive tree.note: Olive tree – Source of oil for anointing and lamps, symbol of peace and blessing (Psalm 52:8; Romans 11:17).

olives.note: Olives – A key agricultural product for oil, light, and anointing (Deuteronomy 8:8; Romans 11:17).

onycha.note: An aromatic ingredient of the holy incense; the exact species is debated (Exodus 30:34).

palm trees.note: Palm – Symbol of victory and rejoicing, used in festivals and Jesus’ triumphal entry (Leviticus 23:40; John 12:13).

papyrus.note: Marsh plant of the Nile used for baskets and books—Moses’ first ark of reeds (Exodus 2:3).

pine.note: Pine – Sometimes translated from Hebrew words referring to temple timber or evergreen trees (Isaiah 41:19).

pistachio.note: Pistachio – One of the choice fruits carried as a gift to Egypt (Genesis 43:11).

plane tree.note: A broad-leafed shade tree known in the Ancient Near East; emblem of sheltering branches.

plant of renown.note: A famous planting from God—promised provision that removes famine’s shame (Ezekiel 34:29, KJV).

pomegranate.note: Pomegranate – A fruit symbolizing fertility and beauty, used in temple design and priestly robes (Exodus 28:33–34).

pomegranate tree.note: Pomegranate tree – Symbol of abundance; used in priestly garments and temple decoration (Exodus 28:33–34).

poplar.note: Poplar – Mentioned among trees planted by water, possibly symbolizing spiritual prosperity (Genesis 30:37; Hosea 4:13).

reed.note: A river plant swayed by wind—measure of fragility and a tool for writing and measuring (3 John 13; Revelation 11:1).

rod that budded.note: Aaron’s staff that blossomed with almond flowers—God’s choice made visible (Numbers 17:8).

root of david.note: Messianic title—both root and offspring, source and fulfillment (Revelation 5:5; 22:16).

rooted by streams.note: Tree planted by water—ever green, yielding fruit in season (Psalm 1:3; Jeremiah 17:8).

rose of sharon.note: A blossom of the plain—humble beauty that hints of the Beloved (Song of Songs 2:1).

rue.note: A garden herb weighed in tithes while weightier matters were neglected (Luke 11:42).

saffron.note: A rare spice of Song’s garden, threads of gold perfuming love’s feast (Song of Songs 4:14).

shoot from the stump.note: A tender shoot springing from what seemed finished—God’s surprising renewal (Isaiah 11:1).

spices.note: Perfumes and aromatics gathered for worship and burial—love’s labor of honor (Mark 16:1).

spikenard.note: Spikenard – A costly perfume used to anoint Jesus before His burial (John 12:3).

stacte.note: A gum resin named in the sacred incense—part of a fragrance not to be copied (Exodus 30:34–38).

sycamore.note: Sycamore – A fig-like tree common in Israel; climbed by Zacchaeus to see Jesus (Amos 7:14; Luke 19:4).

tamarisk.note: A salt-loving tree Abraham planted at Beersheba, calling on the everlasting God (Genesis 21:33).

tares.note: Weeds sown among wheat—lookalikes that only harvest can truly separate (Matthew 13:24–30).

tender plant.note: A fragile sprout despised by many, yet chosen by God (Isaiah 53:2).

thornbush.note: A bristling barrier in parable and proverb—fruitless kingship, scratch of folly (Judges 9:14–15).

thorns.note: The earth’s ache after the fall—pain that Christ bore, crown pressed on His brow (Genesis 3:18; Matthew 27:29).

thyme.note: A low herb of sunny hills—its scent lingers where shepherds rest.

tree of knowledge.note: A boundary in Eden—trust tested between good and evil (Genesis 2:9; 3:6).

tree of life.note: Eden’s central gift and Revelation’s promise—healing leaves and unending fruit (Genesis 2:9; Revelation 22:2).

trees of righteousness.note: People planted by the Lord to display His glory—oaks of praise (Isaiah 61:3).

vine and branches.note: Christ the vine, His people the branches—abiding life that bears much fruit (John 15:5).

vine branch.note: A living shoot that must abide in the vine to bear fruit—image of life in Christ (John 15:1–5).

wheat.note: Wheat – A common grain symbolizing provision, harvest, and spiritual fruit (Matthew 13:24–30).

wild olive.note: A hardy stock grafted in by grace—Gentiles joined to the rich root (Romans 11:17–24).

willow.note: Willow – One of the plants used in the Feast of Tabernacles (Leviticus 23:40).

willow of the brook.note: Graceful trees by the water used in Tabernacles, waving joy before the Lord (Leviticus 23:40).
